posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Piggybacking of of this post started by @Oblarg .  I’ve made an elevator example.  I use a simulated one for testing.

I’ll provide the relevant code below.

A couple of questions related to the original post.

Should one also use other Suppliers as public final fields for pushing out state along with a Trigger(serving a dual role)?  I’m guessing so.

There was some great discussion in the original post about using/not using default Command and periodics.  I’ve decided to write this without using periodics or defaults as an exercise.

Code in the Subsystem.

configure bindings in the RobotContainer.

Thoughts are appreciated

link_counts.title: Command-based best practices for 2025: community feedback
Command-based best practices for 2025: community feedback
Spark Max PID Command Based Structure

posts.name: Jade
posts.cooked:
narmstro:

Should one also use other Suppliers as public final fields for pushing out state along with a Trigger(serving a dual role)?

Depends. If its just BooleanSuppliers dont bother as Trigger’s have the same API for getting their state. On the other hand exposing a supplier from say an encoder or something could be nice. IMO its a pretty niche case as most of the time all state you want to expose can be encapsulated into Triggers.

narmstro:

There was some great discussion in the original post about using/not using default Command and periodics.

I don’t really see the benefits in periodics for much other than for logging unless your subsystem is structured as a state machine but I think most subsystems can be created in much less verbose ways than a state machine. Default Commands are a bit of a different case for me cause I can see very good cases for using default Commands. A good example is our arm this year used a default Command to move into its intaking and speaker shot position. This was the position we wanted it in most of the time as it was also the most stable position for our robot so it made sense to use a default Command. Even in this example you can see that a default Command of control loop disabled probably would’ve had the same impact but been a bit clearer that its the default IMO.

A note on your implementation here I don’t see the benefit of having controlLoopEnable as a seperate factory. Its only used in the setGoal function so it could just be implemented there Personally I’d also make setGoal private and expose its functionality through setpoint functions to make it clear what each position does to the caller (eg for the 2024 game moveToSpeaker , moveToAmp ). An even clearer option would be to make setGoal take an enum that has setpoints then just match the enum to determine where to move it to.

Overall I think its quite a nice example.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
spacey_sooty:

Depends. If its just BooleanSuppliers dont bother as Trigger’s have the same API for getting their state. On the other hand exposing a supplier from say an encoder or something could be nice. IMO its a pretty niche case as most of the time all state you want to expose can be encapsulated into Triggers.

My thought here matches @Oblarg ’s in the original post.  Don’t inject dependencies.  Have the subsystem interaction occur through commands and triggers in RobotContainer.  So having some way to get something like pose estimates from a camera subsystem into a drive subsystem.

spacey_sooty:

Even in this example you can see that a default Command of control loop disabled probably would’ve had the same impact but been a bit clearer that its the default IMO.

Agreed.  I just did it for the challenge/example.  Also I want to stress the point to my students  (and to myself) to be intentional with what is commanded.  Sometimes one forgets the intentionality of default.

spacey_sooty:

A note on your implementation here I don’t see the benefit of having controlLoopEnable as a seperate factory. Its only used in the setGoal function so it could just be implemented there

Good point will modify.

spacey_sooty:

Personally I’d also make setGoal private and expose its functionality through setpoint functions to make it clear what each position does to the caller (eg for the 2024 game moveToSpeaker , moveToAmp ). An even clearer option would be to make setGoal take an enum that has setpoints then just match the enum to determine where to move it to.

I like that idea.  I’ve seen instances of it.  I like my subsystems to be very templated.  This would force me as part of the template to have a spot in Constants the housed the enum.  I guess that could work.

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: It is no longer reccomended to use robotcontainer, i’d update that, it’s reccomended to just put your bindings and stuff in Robot.java

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
spacey_sooty:

benefits in periodics … subsystem is structured as a state machine

That’s only if the state machine (state change) is driven by the periodic clock which I suggest will be an exceedingly rare use for our robots.

My example of a MooreLikeFSM uses Triggers for the state changes and Commands for the states. That’s general purpose and not bound to a clock cycle. (Of course, the command/trigger scheduler is running on the periodic but that’s behind the scenes of our problem space - that’s the point of using Command-Based.)

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Tatiman-Dev:

It is no longer reccomended to use robotcontainer, i’d update that, it’s reccomended to just put your bindings and stuff in Robot.java

I know the PR on allwpilib are headed that way, but I don’t think it’s been officially deprecated yet.  Though I agree putting it up a level higher makes using addPeriodic easier.

I know there is one that makes a CommandRobot template that looks interesting.

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked: This seems to have the problem of the control loop not running when setGoal() is part of a bigger command group, which is why we put the controlLoopEnable() part of the logic in the subsystem’s periodic() method to ensure the subsystem is controlled at all times.

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked:
Can you elaborate on that point?

Also you would necessarily always want it running.  If you manually control it with the joystick you don’t want the loop setting your voltage.

Also if you run sysId (which controls the systems via voltage) you don’t want the control loop interferring.

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked:
For example:

In this case, when this command group is running, the elevator control loop command would not be running when s1.command1() and s2.command2() is running.

Also, the way you implemented elevator.setGoal() means that s1.command4() and s2.command5() would never run.

You can always put an if statement with a boolean around periodic() for when you want to disable continuous control

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: @narmstro - we need the method and code example to support atGoal . Often we want to wait for arrival at the goal before continuing on to run command4 or command5 .

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: You mean a method that holds it at the goal or a method that informs us that we are at the goal.  BooleanSupplier?

posts.name: Nicholas Armstrong
posts.cooked: I have a public final field Trigger for that at the top of the code.  I forgot to show it.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
If I understand what @isaacngkh is saying, there’s a problem with how the setGoal is handled that allows at least 1 cycle where the controlLoopEnable isn’t running, which is not a desired behavior and why the use of periodic and default commands typically becomes the solution. I think the way I’d change this is to make the setGoal call in the initializer.

As for how to handle the large sequence, I’d consider doing two things. First, use the asProxy() decorator to modify the setGoal command and keep the sequence from inheriting the elevator subsystem as a requirement. This will ensure that commands 1 & 2 don’t interrupt the pre-existing instance of controlLoopEnable and cause an extended loss of control.

The second thing I’d consider is making commands 4 & 5 trigger on whatever condition would satisfy the condition of occuring after command 3 or setGoal, maybe the BooleanSupplier of isAtGoal.

It may be desirable to keep the entire sequence together, but without some different specialized decorators that would handle this kind of scenario, I think this is the ‘state machine’ oriented way to handle this case. Thoughts?

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked:
We recently worked on creating a state machine architecture for subsystems, to more easily define the various states and the conditions to transition to another state.

You can view this here in our team repo: GitHub - lasarobotics/PH2024: 2024 Purple Haze FRC , in the “fsm” branch for the intake subsystem.

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked:
Here is how I would approach this:

No need for proxy or state machine set up, and this would run as expected

But this uses periodic() though

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: You don’t need to use an andThen(Commands.waitUntil()) in your setGoal method. Instead, you can directly do runOnce(() -> feedback.setGoal(meters)).until(() -> feedback.atGoal());

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked:
.until() interrupts the decorated command if the condition becomes true before the command finishes normally.

Since runOnce() returns an Instant Command, runOnce(() -> feedback.setGoal(meters)) would finish immediately without waiting for feedback.atGoal() .

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: Ah, you’re right.

posts.name: viggy96
posts.cooked: I still feel this would benefit from a proper state machine though, would clean things up and would be easier to add various defined states for the elevator.

posts.name: Isaac
posts.cooked:
What do you mean by adding various defined states?

I played around with state machine a little but not really seeing its benefits for the amount of work needed to define states and transitions.

If we want to add predefined states, we could just add more commands, like
